markings:
Printed on label, verso below center: CHINA: Japanese napalm bombs destroyed Hankow and left a woman / crying before the wreckage of her home.  It was by such pictures / that Capa tried to depict the pain of a nation fighting for its / life, in 1938    

Stamped, verso center: Please Credit: ROBERT CAPA/ "IMAGES OF WAR" Copyright © 1964

Stamped, verso lower left: DISTRIBUTED BY MAGNUM PHOTOS, INC. / 15 W. 47th St. New York 36, N.Y.

makers.displaydate: 1913–1954; born Budapest, Hungary; died Thai Binh, Vietnam
makers.displaymaker: Robert Capa, 1913–1954; born Budapest, Hungary; died Thai Binh, Vietnam

texts.textentryhtml:
As a backdrop to human drama, the damaged wall is as variable in meaning as it is potent in eff ect. It can instill a reflective mood, strike a note of unease, or supply a symbolic disguise for physical violence too terrible to illustrate directly.

At the heart of Philip Henry Delamotte’s study of Fountains Abbey is a seated figure absorbing the Romantic spirit of the place. An eighteenth-century commentator on garden follies declared that Gothic ruins embody “the triumph of time over
strength”—“a melancholy but not discouraging thought” much preferable to “the triumph of barbarism over taste” that is signified by classical ruins.

Frederick Sommer’s portrait of his Arizona neighbor and friend, surrealist painter Max Ernst, results from the chance alignment of two 8 x 10-inch negatives Sommer held up to the light together. Ernst, commingling with an image of a stained cement wall, becomes a spectral presence, as compelling and uncanny as a figure in a dream.

Between Japanese bombardments of Hankow (Wuhan), China, in October 1938, Robert Capa recorded a scene that sums up the city’s physical and moral devastation: surrounded by malarial standing water, a woman with bound
feet crouches in tears before the shell of a splintered house.
texts.remarks: The Life and Death of Buildings
